item.content:encoded:
The Isha Upanishad stands as one of the foremost philosophical scriptures in Hinduism, encapsulating the essence of Vedic wisdom in a concise and profound manner. it delves deep into the nature of the Self and the universe, embodying the core tenets of monism and spiritual unity. The Upanishad derives its name from the first word of the text, “Isha,” which means “Lord” or “Ruler,” reflecting the idea of a divine presence pervading everything.

The Isha Upanishad is found embedded as the final chapter of the Shukla (White) Yajurveda. Comprising just 18 verses, it is one of the shortest Upanishads. It is a Mukhya Upanishad, and is found in both recensions of the Shukla Yajuerveda, the Kanva and Madhyandina. Isha Upanishad is the only Upanishad that is attached to a Samhita, the most ancient layer of Vedic texts. Other Upanishads are typically attached to Brahmanas or Aranyakas.

At the heart of the Isha Upanishad is the concept of renunciation and enjoyment – living in the world yet remaining detached from its transient nature. This spiritual vision encourages a life of balance, where one can engage with the world and its duties without being entangled by material possessions or desires.

Its teachings revolve around the recognition that the divine essence is immanent in all beings and the cosmos. It suggests that true liberation and wisdom come from recognizing the imperishable amidst the perishable, the infinite within the finite. It challenges the dualistic perception of reality, urging the seeker to see beyond the apparent multiplicity to the underlying unity.

This timeless wisdom continues to inspire seekers of truth, guiding them toward a deeper understanding of their own nature and the universe.

Isha Upanishad

the final chapter of the Shukla Yajurveda

Invocation

It is complete there, it is complete here.
Complete arises from that which is complete.
Once Complete is taken from the Complete,
What remains is still complete.

Isha Upanishad

Isha inhabits all, whatsoever that moves in this dynamic universe.
We should enjoy that which we have received from its sacrifice,
Do not long for any other person’s wealth.

Doing what is to be done,
One should wish to live a hundred years.
It is in you and not otherwise,
Actions do not cling to a man.

Sunless are those worlds, covered in blind darkness,
That ones go to who slay their souls.

That, unmoving, moves swifter than thought.
Even Gods cannot reach as it goes ever in front.
That, standing, passes others that run.
It is in Its waters that Matarishva sprints.

That moves and That moves not.
That seems far and yet That is near.
That which is within this all,
Is as well outside it.

He who sees all of creation within themselves,
And Self no different from all of creation,
There is nothing that remains hidden from him.

He who understands that all of creation is no different from the Self,
How can there be any attachment or grief,
Where one sees just oneness.

That has gone out, that which is bright, bodiless, without scar or imperfection, without sinews, pure, unpierced by evil.
The Seer, the Thinker, the One who becomes all, the Self-existent who has ordered objects according to their nature from the very beginning.

Into blind darkness enter those who persist in Ignorance,
Yet into a greater darkness go those,
Who devote themselves to Knowledge alone.

That which comes from Knowledge is different
From that which comes from Ignorance.
So the wise have told us and revealed to our understanding.

He who knows That as both Knowledge and Ignorance,
Through Ignorance crosses over death and,
Through Knowledge enjoys immortality.

Into blind darkness enter those who go after Non-existence,
Yet into a greater darkness go those who go after Existence.

That which comes from Existence is different,
From that which comes from Non-existence.
So the wise have told us and revealed to our understanding.

He who knows That as both Existence and Non-Existence,
Through Non-Existence crosses over death and,
Through Existence enjoys immortality.

Covered by a golden lid is the face of Truth.
That, Pushan, you must remove to see the True Law.

O sole seer, O ordainer, O illuminating sun,
O power of the master of creatures, marshal your rays,
Draw together your light; the luster which is your most blessed form, That in You I behold, the Purusha both there and here,
(Sohamasmi) That am I.

Vayu and Anil are immortal,
This body’s destination is ashes.
Remember the purpose, remember what was done.
Remember the purpose, remember what was done.

Agni, lead us, the people of Deva,
By the good path to clear knowledge,
Remove from us the devious attraction of sin.
To you we submit our speech.

Detailed Translation

Invocation

ॐ पूर्णमदः पूर्णमिदं पूर्णात् पूर्णमुदच्यते ।
पूर्णस्य पूर्णमादाय पूर्णमेवावशिष्यते ॥

oṃ pūrṇamadaḥ pūrṇamidaṃ pūrṇāt pūrṇamudacyate ।
pūrṇasya pūrṇamādāya pūrṇamevāvaśiṣyate ॥

It is complete there, it is complete here.
Complete arises from that which is complete.
Once Complete is taken from the Complete,
What remains is still complete.

Isha Upanishad

ईशा वास्यमिदं सर्वं यत्किञ्च जगत्यां जगत् ।
तेन त्यक्तेन भुञ्जीथा मा गृधः कस्य स्विद्धनम् ॥१॥

īśā vāsyamidaṃ sarvaṃ yatkiñca jagatyāṃ jagat ।
tena tyaktena bhuñjīthā mā gṛdhaḥ kasya sviddhanam ॥


Isha inhabits all, whatsoever that moves in this dynamic universe.
We should enjoy that which we have received from its sacrifice,
Do not long for any other person’s wealth.

कुर्वन्नेवेह कर्माणि जिजीविषेच्छतं समाः ।
एवं त्वयि नान्यथेतोऽस्ति न कर्म लिप्यते नरे ॥२॥

kurvanneveha karmāṇi jijīviṣecchataṃ samāḥ ।
evaṃ tvayi nānyatheto’sti na karma lipyate nare ॥


Doing what is to be done,
One should wish to live a hundred years.
It is in you and not otherwise,
Actions do not cling to a man.

असुर्या नाम ते लोका अन्धेन तमसा वृताः ।
तांस्ते प्रेत्याभिगच्छन्ति ये के चात्महनो जनाः ॥३॥

asuryā nāma te lokā andhena tamasā vṛtāḥ ।
tāṃste pretyābhigacchanti ye ke cātmahano janāḥ ॥


Sunless are those worlds, covered in blind darkness,
That ones go to who slay their souls.

अनेजदेकं मनसो जवीयो नैनद्देवा आप्नुवन्पूर्वमर्षत् ।
तद्धावतोऽन्यानत्येति तिष्ठत्तस्मिन्नपो मातरिश्वा दधाति ॥ ४ ॥

anejadekaṃ manaso javīyo nainaddevā āpnuvanpūrvamarṣat ।
taddhāvato’nyānatyeti tiṣṭhattasminnapo mātariśvā dadhāti ॥


That, unmoving, moves swifter than thought.
Even Gods cannot reach as it goes ever in front.
That, standing, passes others that run.
It is in Its waters that Matarishva sprints.

तदेजति तन्नैजति तद्दूरे तद्वन्तिके ।
तदन्तरस्य सर्वस्य तदु सर्वस्यास्य बाह्यतः ॥५॥

tadejati tannaijati taddūre tadvantike ।
tadantarasya sarvasya tadu sarvasyāsya bāhyataḥ ॥


That moves and That moves not.
That seems far and yet That is near.
That which is within this all,
Is as well outside it.

यस्तु सर्वाणि भूतानि आत्मन्येवानुपश्यति ।
सर्वभूतेषु चात्मानं ततो न विजुगुप्सते ॥६॥

yastu sarvāṇi bhūtāni ātmanyevānupaśyati ।
sarvabhūteṣu cātmānaṃ tato na vijugupsate ॥


He who sees all of creation within themselves,
And Self no different from all of creation,
There is nothing that remains hidden from him.

यस्मिन्सर्वाणि भूतानि आत्मैवाभूद्विजानतः ।
तत्र को मोहः कः शोक एकत्वमनुपश्यतः ॥७॥

yasminsarvāṇi bhūtāni ātmaivābhūdvijānataḥ ।
tatra ko mohaḥ kaḥ śoka ekatvamanupaśyataḥ ॥


He who understands that all of creation is no different from the Self,
How can there be any attachment or grief,
Where one sees just oneness.

स पर्यगाच्छुक्रमकायमव्रणमस्नाविरं शुद्धमपापविद्धम् ।
कविर्मनीषी परिभूः स्वयम्भूर्याथातथ्यतोऽर्थान्व्यदधाच्छाश्वतीभ्यः समाभ्यः ॥८॥

sa paryagācchukramakāyamavraṇamasnāviraṃ śuddhamapāpaviddham ।
kavirmanīṣī paribhūḥ svayambhūryāthātathyato’rthānvyadadhācchāśvatībhyaḥ samābhyaḥ ॥


That has gone out, that which is bright, bodiless, without scar or imperfection, without sinews, pure, unpierced by evil.
The Seer, the Thinker, the One who becomes all, the Self-existent who has ordered objects according to their nature from the very beginning.

अन्धं तमः प्रविशन्ति ये अविद्यामुपासते ।
ततो भूय इव ते तमो य उ विद्यायां रताः ॥९॥

andhaṃ tamaḥ praviśanti ye avidyāmupāsate ।
tato bhūya iva te tamo ya u vidyāyāṃ ratāḥ ॥


Into blind darkness enter those who persist in Ignorance,
Yet into a greater darkness go those,
Who devote themselves to Knowledge alone.

अन्यदेवाहुर्विद्यया अन्यदाहुरविद्यया ।
इति शुश्रुम धीराणां ये नस्तद्विचचक्षिरे ॥१०॥

anyadevāhurvidyayā anyadāhuravidyayā ।
iti śuśruma dhīrāṇāṃ ye nastadvicacakṣire ॥

That which comes from Knowledge is different
From that which comes from Ignorance.
So the wise have told us and revealed to our understanding.

विद्यां चाविद्यां च यस्तद्वेदोभयं सह ।
अविद्यया मृत्युं तीर्त्वा विद्ययामृतमश्नुते ॥११॥

vidyāṃ cāvidyāṃ ca yastadvedobhayaṃ saha ।
avidyayā mṛtyuṃ tīrtvā vidyayāmṛtamaśnute ॥

He who knows That as both Knowledge and Ignorance,
Through Ignorance crosses over death and,
Through Knowledge enjoys immortality.

अन्धं तमः प्रविशन्ति येऽसम्भूतिमुपासते ।
ततो भूय इव ते तमो य उ सम्भूत्यां रताः ॥१२॥

andhaṃ tamaḥ praviśanti ye’sambhūtimupāsate ।
tato bhūya iva te tamo ya u sambhūtyāṃ ratāḥ ॥

Into blind darkness enter those who go after Non-existence,
Yet into a greater darkness go those who go after Existence.

अन्यदेवाहुः सम्भवादन्यदाहुरसम्भवात् ।
इति शुश्रुम धीराणां ये नस्तद्विचचक्षिरे ॥१३॥

andhaṃ tamaḥ praviśanti ye avidyāmupāsate ।
tato bhūya iva te tamo ya u vidyāyāṃ ratāḥ ॥

That which comes from Existence is different,
From that which comes from Non-existence.
So the wise have told us and revealed to our understanding.

सम्भूतिं च विनाशं च यस्तद्वेदोभयं सह ।
विनाशेन मृत्युं तीर्त्वा सम्भूत्यामृतमश्नुते ॥१४॥

sambhūtiṃ ca vināśaṃ ca yastadvedobhayaṃ saha ।
vināśena mṛtyuṃ tīrtvā sambhūtyāmṛtamaśnute ॥

He who knows That as both Existence and Non-Existence,
Through Non-Existence crosses over death and,
Through Existence enjoys immortality.

हिरण्मयेन पात्रेण सत्यस्यापिहितं मुखम् ।
तत्त्वं पूषन्नपावृणु सत्यधर्माय दृष्टये ॥१५॥

hiraṇmayena pātreṇa satyasyāpihitaṃ mukham ।
tattvaṃ pūṣannapāvṛṇu satyadharmāya dṛṣṭaye ॥

Covered by a golden lid is the face of Truth.
That, Pushan, you must remove to see the True Law.

पूषन्नेकर्षे यम सूर्य प्राजापत्य व्यूह
रश्मीन्समूह तेजो यत्ते रूपं कल्याणतमं
तत्ते पश्यामि योऽसावसौ पुरुषः सोऽहमस्मि ॥१६॥

pūṣannekarṣe yama sūrya prājāpatya vyūha
raśmīnsamūha tejo yatte rūpaṃ kalyāṇatamaṃ
tatte paśyāmi yo’sāvasau puruṣaḥ so’hamasmi ॥

O sole seer, O ordainer, O illuminating sun,
O power of the master of creatures, marshal your rays,
Draw together your light; the lustre which is your most blessed form,
That in You I behold, the Purusha both there and here,
(Sohamasmi) That am I.

वायुरनिलममृतमथेदं भस्मान्तं शरीरम् ।
ओं क्रतो स्मर कृतं स्मर क्रतो स्मर कृतं स्मर ॥१७॥

vāyuranilamamṛtamathedaṃ bhasmāntaṃ śarīram ।
oṃ krato smara kṛtaṃ smara krato smara kṛtaṃ smara ॥

Vayu and Anil are immortal,
This body’s destination is ashes.
Remember the purpose, remember what was done.
Remember the purpose, remember what was done.

अग्ने नय सुपथा राये अस्मान्विश्वानि देव वयुनानि विद्वान् ।
युयोध्यस्मज्जुहुराणमेनो भूयिष्ठां ते नमउक्तिं विधेम ॥१८॥

agne naya supathā rāye asmānviśvāni deva vayunāni vidvān ।
yuyodhyasmajjuhurāṇameno bhūyiṣṭhāṃ te namauktiṃ vidhema ॥


Agni, lead us, the people of Deva,
By the good path to clear knowledge,
Remove from us the devious attraction of sin.
To you we submit our speech.

Translated by Devajyoti Sarkar

item.content:encoded:
The Kena Upanishad starts by asking when we think, who is it that is thinking, when we speak who is it that speaks. It is one of the most profound of the ten Principal Upanishads of the Indian philosophical tradition. It was the first one I read and it started me on a life long quest to learn more. For me, this encapsulates what spirituality means and even so far as today it is my favorite.

Upanishads are called Vedanta, the end of the Vedas. They are what you close your Vedic education with. “Upanishad” means “at the feet of”, perhaps symbolizing the final advice that you get from your Guru, before you start your life in the real world.

“Kena” means “by whom”. The Kena Upanishad is one of the ten Principal Upanishads laid out by scholars like Adi Shankara and Madhavacharya. It is the second in the Muktika canon of 108 Upanishads. This primarily focuses on the concept of Brahman, the ultimate reality or universal consciousness. It is structured as a set of questions whose answers beget more questions. It is divided into four sections, in this post we will cover the first two.

The Kena Upanishad has had a profound significance in Hindu philosophy. It explores the nature of consciousness and the relationship between the individual self (Atman) and the ultimate reality (Brahman). Kena’s teachings have influenced various schools of Hinduism, including Advaita Vedanta, which advocates non-dualistic identity of the individual soul and Brahman.

Kena Upanishad

from the Talavakara Brahmana of the Samaveda

By whom propelled does the mind’s arrow fall on its target.
By whom yoked do we take our first breath.
By whom willed do we express our speech,
Our eyes, our hearing, by whom are they driven.

That which is the hearing in our hearing, the mind of our mind,
The voice of our speech, the life in our breath and,
The sight of our eyes. This has been told to us by the wise,
Who released from this world have become immortal.

There sight cannot not travel,
Nor our words nor our thoughts.
We can not know it, nor can we understand it,
So how does one explain it.

It is above what is known and beneath what is unknown.
Thus we have learned from the ancients who explained it to us.

That which cannot be expressed by word,
But that by which words find expression.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

That which does not think with a mind,
But that by which our mind finds its thoughts.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

That which does not see with eyes,
But that through which our eyes finds its sight.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

That which does not listen with ears,
But that through which our ears listen.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

That which does not live by breathing,
But that by which life comes to our breath.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

End of the first section of the Kena Upanishad



If you think you know it well,
Little indeed do you know the form of the Brahman.
That of which is you and that of which is in the gods,
This you must discover, I think it can be known.

I do not think I know It well,
Nor is It unknown to me.
He of us who knows It knows that.
He knows that It is not unknown to him.

That which by not thinking is thought,
And that by thinking cannot be known.
That by not discerning is discerned,
And by discerning cannot be understood.

When the mind is possessed with understanding,
it truly is immortality that one finds.
Through the Atma one finds energy,
Through Knowledge one finds immortality.

If one has known It here then there is truth.
If one has not, great is the destruction.
Discerning It in all of creation, the wise
are released from this world and become immortal.

End of the second section of the Kena Upanishad

Detailed Translation

ॐ
केनेषितं पतति प्रेषितं मनः
केन प्राणः प्रथमः प्रैति युक्तः।
केनेषितां वाचमिमां वदन्ति
चक्शुः श्रोत्रं क उ देवो युनक्ति॥१॥

keneṣitaṃ patati preṣitaṃ manaḥ
kena prāṇaḥ prathamaḥ praiti yuktaḥ।
keneṣitāṃ vācamimāṃ vadanti
cakśuḥ śrotraṃ ka u devo yunakti॥

By whom propelled does the mind’s arrow fall on its target.
By whom yoked do we take our first breath.
By whom willed do we express in our speech,
Our eyes, our hearing, by whom are they driven.

श्रोत्रस्य श्रोत्रं मनसो मनो यद्‌
वाचो ह वाचं स उ प्राणस्य प्राणः।
चक्शुषश्चक्शुरतिमुच्य धीराः
प्रेत्यास्माल्लोकादमृता भवन्ति॥२॥

śrotrasya śrotraṃ manaso mano yad‌
vāco ha vācaṃ sa u prāṇasya prāṇaḥ।
cakśuṣaścakśuratimucya dhīrāḥ
pretyāsmāllokādamṛtā bhavanti॥

That which is the hearing in our hearing, the mind of our mind,
The voice of our speech, the life in our breath and,
The sight of our eyes. This has been told to us by the wise,
Who released from this world have become immortal.

न तत्र चक्शुर्गच्छति न वाग्गच्छति नो मनः।
न विद्मो न विजानीमो यथैतदनुशिष्यात्‌॥३॥

na tatra cakśurgacchati na vāggacchati no manaḥ।
na vidmo na vijānīmo yathaitadanuśiṣyāt‌॥

There sight cannot not travel,
Nor our words nor our thoughts.
We can not know it, nor can we understand it,
So how does one explain it.

अन्यदेव तद्विदितादथो अविदितादधि।
इति शुश्रुम पूर्वेषां ये नस्तद्‌व्याचचक्शिरे॥४॥

anyadeva tadviditādatho aviditādadhi।
iti śuśruma pūrveṣāṃ ye nastad‌vyācacakśire॥

It is above what is known and beneath what is unknown.
Thus we have learned from the ancients who explained it to us.

यद्वाचाऽनभ्युदितं येन वागभ्युद्यते।
तदेव ब्रह्म त्वं विद्धि नेदं यदिदमुपासते॥५॥

yadvācā’nabhyuditaṃ yena vāgabhyudyate।
tadeva brahma tvaṃ viddhi nedaṃ yadidamupāsate॥

That which cannot be expressed by word,
But that by which words find expression.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

यन्मनसा न मनुते येनाहुर्मनो मतम्‌।
तदेव ब्रह्म त्वं विद्धि नेदं यदिदमुपासते॥६॥

yanmanasā na manute yenāhurmano matam‌।
tadeva brahma tvaṃ viddhi nedaṃ yadidamupāsate॥

That which does not think with a mind,
But that by which our mind finds its thoughts.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

यच्चक्शुषा न पश्यति येन चक्शूँषि पश्यति।
तदेव ब्रह्म त्वं विद्धि नेदं यदिदमुपासते॥७॥

yaccakśuṣā na paśyati yena cakśū~ṣi paśyati।
tadeva brahma tvaṃ viddhi nedaṃ yadidamupāsate॥

That which does not see with eyes,
But that through which our eyes finds its sight.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

यच्छ्रोत्रेण न शृणोति येन श्रोत्रमिदं श्रुतम्‌।
तदेव ब्रह्म त्वं विद्धि नेदं यदिदमुपासते॥८॥

yacchrotreṇa na śṛṇoti yena śrotramidaṃ śrutam‌।
tadeva brahma tvaṃ viddhi nedaṃ yadidamupāsate॥

That which does not listen with ears,
But that through which our ears listen.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

यत्प्राणेन न प्राणिति येन प्राणः प्रणीयते।
तदेव ब्रह्म त्वं विद्धि नेदं यदिदमुपासते॥९॥

yatprāṇena na prāṇiti yena prāṇaḥ praṇīyate।
tadeva brahma tvaṃ viddhi nedaṃ yadidamupāsate॥

That which does not live by breathing,
But that by which life comes to our breath.
Know that as Brahma, not what people worship here.

॥ इति केनोपनिषदि प्रथमः खण्डः॥

End of the first section of the Kena Upanishad

यदि मन्यसे सुवेदेति दहरमेवापि
नूनं त्वं वेत्थ ब्रह्मणो रूपम्‌।
यदस्य त्वं यदस्य देवेष्वथ नु
मीमाँस्येमेव ते मन्ये विदितम्‌॥१॥

yadi manyase suvedeti daharamevāpi
nūnaṃ tvaṃ vettha brahmaṇo rūpam‌।
yadasya tvaṃ yadasya deveṣvatha nu
mīmā~syemeva te manye viditam‌॥

If you think you know it well,
Little indeed do you know the form of the Brahman.
That of which is you and that of which is in the gods,
This you must discover, I think it can be known.

नाहं मन्ये सुवेदेति नो न वेदेति वेद च।
यो नस्तद्वेद तद्वेद नो न वेदेति वेद च॥२॥

nāhaṃ manye suvedeti no na vedeti veda ca।
yo nastadveda tadveda no na vedeti veda ca॥

I do not think I know It well,
Nor is It unknown to me.
He of us who knows It knows that.
He knows that It is not unknown to him.

यस्यामतं तस्य मतं मतं यस्य न वेद सः।
अविज्ञातं विजानतां विज्ञातमविजानताम्‌॥३॥

yasyāmataṃ tasya mataṃ mataṃ yasya na veda saḥ।
avijñātaṃ vijānatāṃ vijñātamavijānatām‌॥

That which by not thinking is thought,
And that by thinking cannot be known.
That by not discerning is discerned,
And by discerning cannot be understood.

प्रतिबोधविदितं मतममृतत्वं हि विन्दते।
आत्मना विन्दते वीर्यं विद्यया विन्दतेऽमृतम्‌॥४॥

pratibodhaviditaṃ matamamṛtatvaṃ hi vindate।
ātmanā vindate vīryaṃ vidyayā vindate’mṛtam‌॥

When the mind is possessed with understanding,
it truly is immortality that one finds.
Through the Atma one finds energy,
Through Knowledge one finds immortality.

इह चेदवेदीदथ सत्यमस्ति
न चेदिहावेदीन्महती विनष्टिः।
भूतेषु भूतेषु विचित्य धीराः
प्रेत्यास्माल्लोकादमृता भवन्ति॥५॥

iha cedavedīdatha satyamasti
na cedihāvedīnmahatī vinaṣṭiḥ।
bhūteṣu bhūteṣu vicitya dhīrāḥ
pretyāsmāllokādamṛtā bhavanti॥

If one has known It here then there is truth.
If one has not, great is the destruction.
Discerning It in all of creation, the wise,
are released from this world and become immortal.

॥ इति केनोपनिषदि द्वितीयः खण्डः॥

End of the second section of the Kena Upanishad

Translated by Devajyoti Sarkar

item.content:encoded:
The Devi Sukta of the Rig Veda is a foundational text for the Shakta tradition of Hinduism. Centered on the worship of the Divine Feminine in various forms, this tradition draws heavily upon the Devi Sukta’s depiction of the goddess as the ultimate reality and the source of all creation. Its emphasis on the Devi is a significant departure from traditional patriarchal narratives.

The Rishika of this Sukta is Vaak Ambhrini and the Devata is Vaak Ambhrini herself. It is the Devi who is reciting her own Sukta of praise. There are a number of Rishikas, female Rishis, who have composed key Suktas for the Rig Veda, although the majority are male. There are also a number of Suktas which are structured as self-praise where both the Rishi and Devata are the same but they are relatively rare.

In its structure and style, the Devi Sukta stands alone.

Rig Veda 10.125

Rishika: Vaak Ambhrini
Devata: Vaak Ambhrini

I move with the Rudras and the Vasus,
With the Adityas and Vishvadevas I,
I sustain both Mitra and Varuna,
Indra and Agni, and the two Ashvins.

I press the Soma,
I sustain Tvashtar with Pushan and Bhaga.
I give wealth to the sacrificer,
Who praises well and offers oblation.

I am Queen, I collect treasure,
I am radiant, the first of worship,
I have put the Gods in many places,
Mighty stations where only the mighty enter.

Through me (they) eat food, who sees, who breathes,
Who hears words spoken (does so through me),
They who do not think of me perish,
Those who can hear, I tell what is worth hearing.

I, and I alone, speak that,
Which adorns both gods and men,
Those I love I make mighty,
Make him a brahman, a rishi and a sage.

I bend Rudra’s bow so that his arrow,
May slay those who hate Brahma,
I do battle for the people,
I permeate both heaven and earth.

I arose from my father’s forehead,
My womb is Apsu at the ocean’s end,
There I stand with the land of the Anu,
The Amu touch the heaven through my body.

It is I who makes the wind blow,
I commenced (the creation) of all worlds,
Beyond heaven, beyond earth,
So vast am I in greatness.

Detailed Translation

अ॒हं रु॒द्रेभि॒र्वसु॑भिश्चराम्य॒हमा॑दि॒त्यैरु॒त वि॒श्वदे॑वैः ।
अ॒हं मि॒त्रावरु॑णो॒भा बि॑भर्म्य॒हमि॑न्द्रा॒ग्नी अ॒हम॒श्विनो॒भा ॥१॥

अहम् । रुद्रेभिः । वसुभिः । चरामि । अहम् । आदित्यैः । उत । विश्वदेवैः ।
अहम् । मित्रावरुणा । उभा । बिभर्मि । अहम् । इन्द्राग्नी इति । अहम् । अश्विना । उभा ॥

ahaṃ rudrebhirvasubhiścarāmyahamādityairuta viśvadevaiḥ ।
ahaṃ mitrāvaruṇobhā bibharmyahamindrāgnī ahamaśvinobhā ॥

I move with the Rudras and the Vasus,
With the Adityas and Vishvadevas I,
I sustain both Mitra and Varuna,
Indra and Agni, and the two Ashvins.

अ॒हं सोम॑माह॒नसं॑ बिभर्म्य॒हं त्वष्टा॑रमु॒त पू॒षणं॒ भग॑म् ।
अ॒हं द॑धामि॒ द्रवि॑णं ह॒विष्म॑ते सुप्रा॒व्ये॒३॒॑ यज॑मानाय सुन्व॒ते ॥२॥

अहम् । सोमम् । आहनसम् । बिभर्मि । अहम् । त्वष्टारम् । उत । पूषणम् । भगम् ।
अहम् । दधामि । द्रविणम् । हविष्मते । सुप्रअव्ये । यजमानाय । सुन्वते ॥

ahaṃ somamāhanasaṃ bibharmyahaṃ tvaṣṭāramuta pūṣaṇaṃ bhagam ।
ahaṃ dadhāmi draviṇaṃ haviṣmate suprāvye yajamānāya sunvate ॥

I press the Soma,
I sustain Tvashtar with Pushan and Bhaga.
I give wealth to the sacrificer,
Who praises well and offers oblation.

अ॒हं राष्ट्री॑ सं॒गम॑नी॒ वसू॑नां चिकि॒तुषी॑ प्रथ॒मा य॒ज्ञिया॑नाम् ।
तां मा॑ दे॒वा व्य॑दधुः पुरु॒त्रा भूरि॑स्थात्रां॒ भूर्या॑वे॒शय॑न्तीम् ॥३॥

अहम् । राष्ट्री । सम्गमनी । वसूनाम् । चिकितुषी । प्रथमा । यज्ञियानाम् ।
ताम् । मा । देवाः । वि । अदधुः । पुरुत्रा । भूरिस्थात्राम् । भूरि । आवेशयन्तीम् ॥

ahaṃ rāṣṭrī saṃgamanī vasūnāṃ cikituṣī prathamā yajñiyānām ।
tāṃ mā devā vyadadhuḥ purutrā bhūristhātrāṃ bhūryāveśayantīm ॥

I am Queen, I collect treasure,
I am radiant, the first of worship,
I have put the Gods in many places,
Mighty stations where only the mighty enter.

मया॒ सो अन्न॑मत्ति॒ यो वि॒पश्य॑ति॒ यः प्राणि॑ति॒ य ईं॑ शृ॒णोत्यु॒क्तम् ।
अ॒म॒न्तवो॒ मां त उप॑ क्षियन्ति श्रु॒धि श्रु॑त श्रद्धि॒वं ते॑ वदामि ॥४॥

मया । सः । अन्नम् । अत्ति । यः । विपश्यति । यः । प्राणिति । यः । ईम् । शृणोति ।
उक्तम् । अमन्तवः । माम् । ते । उप । क्षियन्ति । श्रुधि । श्रुत । श्रद्धिवम् । ते । वदामि ॥

mayā so annamatti yo vipaśyati yaḥ prāṇiti ya īṃ śṛṇotyuktam ।
amantavo māṃ ta upa kṣiyanti śrudhi śruta śraddhivaṃ te vadāmi ॥

Through me (they) eat food, who sees, who breathes,
Who hears words spoken (does so through me),
They who do not think of me perish,
Those who can hear, I tell what is worth hearing.

अ॒हमे॒व स्व॒यमि॒दं व॑दामि॒ जुष्टं॑ दे॒वेभि॑रु॒त मानु॑षेभिः ।
यं का॒मये॒ तंत॑मु॒ग्रं कृ॑णोमि॒ तं ब्र॒ह्माणं॒ तमृषिं॒ तं सु॑मे॒धाम् ॥५॥

अहम् । एव । स्वयम् । इदम् । वदामि । जुष्टम् । देवेभिः । उत । मानुषेभिः ।
यम् । कामये । तम्तम् । उग्रम् । कृणोमि । तम् । ब्रह्माणम् । तम् । ऋषिम् । तम् । सुमेधाम् ॥

ahameva svayamidaṃ vadāmi juṣṭaṃ devebhiruta mānuṣebhiḥ ।
yaṃ kāmaye taṃtamugraṃ kṛṇomi taṃ brahmāṇaṃ tamṛṣiṃ taṃ sumedhām ॥

I, and I alone, speak that,
Which adorns both gods and men,
Those I love I make mighty,
Make him a brahman, a rishi and a sage.

अ॒हं रु॒द्राय॒ धनु॒रा त॑नोमि ब्रह्म॒द्विषे॒ शर॑वे॒ हन्त॒वा उ॑ ।
अ॒हं जना॑य स॒मदं॑ कृणोम्य॒हं द्यावा॑पृथि॒वी आ वि॑वेश ॥६॥

अहम् । रुद्राय । धनुः । आ । तनोमि । ब्रह्मद्विषे । शरवे । हन्तवै । ऊँ इति ।
अहम् । जनाय । समदम् । कृणोमि । अहम् । द्यावापृथिवी इति । आ । विवेश ॥

ahaṃ rudrāya dhanurā tanomi brahmadviṣe śarave hantavā u ।
ahaṃ janāya samadaṃ kṛṇomyahaṃ dyāvāpṛthivī ā viveśa ॥

I bend Rudra’s bow so that his arrow,
May slay those who hate Brahma,
I do battle for the people,
I permeate both heaven and earth.

अ॒हं सु॑वे पि॒तर॑मस्य मू॒र्धन्मम॒ योनि॑र॒प्स्व१॒॑न्तः स॑मु॒द्रे ।
ततो॒ वि ति॑ष्ठे॒ भुव॒नानु॒ विश्वो॒तामूं द्यां व॒र्ष्मणोप॑ स्पृशामि ॥७॥

अहम् । सुवे । पितरम् । अस्य । मूर्धन् । मम । योनिः । अप्सु । अन्तरिति । समुद्रे ।
ततः । वि । तिष्ठे । भुवना । अनु । विश्वा । उत । अमूम् । द्याम् । वर्ष्मणा । उप । स्पृशामि ॥

ahaṃ suve pitaramasya mūrdhanmama yonirapsvantaḥ samudre ।
tato vi tiṣṭhe bhuvanānu viśvotāmūṃ dyāṃ varṣmaṇopa spṛśāmi ॥

I arose from my father’s forehead,
My womb is Apsu at the ocean’s end,
There I stand with the land of the Anu,
The Amu touch the heaven through my body.

अ॒हमे॒व वात॑ इव॒ प्र वा॑म्या॒रभ॑माणा॒ भुव॑नानि॒ विश्वा॑ ।
प॒रो दि॒वा प॒र ए॒ना पृ॑थि॒व्यैताव॑ती महि॒ना सं ब॑भूव ॥८॥

अहम् । एव । वातःइव । प्र । वामि । आरभमाणा । भुवनानि । विश्वा ।
परः । दिवा । परः । एना । पृथिव्या । एतावती । महिना । सम् । बभूव ॥

ahameva vāta iva pra vāmyārabhamāṇā bhuvanāni viśvā ।
paro divā para enā pṛthivyaitāvatī mahinā saṃ babhūva ॥

It is I who makes the wind blow,
I commenced (the creation) of all worlds,
Beyond heaven, beyond earth,
So vast am I in greatness.

Translated by Devajyoti Sarkar

item.content:encoded:
Rig Veda 6.27 stands out for its vivid depiction of Indra’s triumph over the Vricvants at the battles of Hariyupia and Yavyavati. This hymn comes from Mandala 6 which is known as the Bharadvaja family mandala. Composed by the sage Bharadvaja Barhaspatya and dedicated to Indra, this hymn not only celebrates the might of Indra but also offers a glimpse into the martial and ritualistic aspects of Vedic society.

In this particular hymn, Bharadvaja Barhaspatya narrates the fierce encounter where Indra, the king of gods and the deity of thunder and war, fights against the Vricvants. The battle scenes are described as a first person account where Bharadvaja was himself a participant of the battle as the priest officiating the rites for this occasion. It highlights the valor and prowess of Indra as he overcomes his adversaries and ends their line. He ends the Sukta with a Danastuti to his patron Abhyavartin Chayamana for the gifts he received as rewards for his services. There are 20 Danastutis in the Rig Veda, each commemorating the generosity of the Rishi’s patrons for his services, many at a pivotal battle in the history of the Vedic peoples.

Not only are the individuals and the peoples of this early battle lost to time, it is grounded in a geography that is no longer understood. The mention of locations such as Hariyupia and Yavyavati are examples of the many places in the Rig Veda which can no longer be matched to actual places. No one today knows where they were.

Rig Veda 6.27

Rishi: Bharadvaja Barhaspatya
Devata: Indra

Drunk and intoxicated (with Soma),
In his friendship, what has Indra done,
At the feet of the battle, what did he acquire,
Of the past and what of the future.

Drunk and intoxicated with the Truth and,
In Truth’s friendship has Indra done,
At the feet of the battle he acquired,
The Truth of the past and the Truth of the future.

We do not know your vast powers, Maghvan,
The fullness of your greatness,
Nor has anyone seen (the like) of your,
Ever renewing generosity, O Indra.

There is one that we have witnessed,
When you slew Varashikha’s end,
Even the thunderclap of your lightning bolt,
Was enough to destroy their best.

For Abhyavartin Chayamana,
Indra destroyed Varasikha’s line.
At Hariyupiya he smote the vanguard,
Of the Vrcivat and their rear fled frightened.

Thirty hundred armor-clad together,
On the Yavyavati, O much-sought after Indra,
Vrcivat’s sons fell to arrows,
Like bursting vessels and met their end.

Two chariots of fire bridled with twenty oxen,
My generous lord gave me.
This imperishable gift of the Parthavas,
Was given to me by Abhyavartin Chayamana.

Detailed Translation

किम॑स्य॒ मदे॒ किम्व॑स्य पी॒ताविन्द्र॒: किम॑स्य स॒ख्ये च॑कार ।
रणा॑ वा॒ ये नि॒षदि॒ किं ते अ॑स्य पु॒रा वि॑विद्रे॒ किमु॒ नूत॑नासः ॥१॥

किम् । अस्य । मदे । किम् । ऊँ इति । अस्य । पीतौ । इन्द्रः । किम् । अस्य । सख्ये । चकार ।
रणाः । वा । ये । निसदि । किम् । ते । अस्य । पुरा । विविद्रे । किम् । ऊँ इति । नूतनासः ॥

kimasya made kimvasya pītāvindraḥ kimasya sakhye cakāra ।
raṇā vā ye niṣadi kiṃ te asya purā vividre kimu nūtanāsaḥ ॥

Drunk and intoxicated (with Soma),
In his friendship, what has Indra done,
At the feet of the battle, what did he acquire,
Of the past and what of the future.

सद॑स्य॒ मदे॒ सद्व॑स्य पी॒ताविन्द्र॒: सद॑स्य स॒ख्ये च॑कार ।
रणा॑ वा॒ ये नि॒षदि॒ सत्ते अ॑स्य पु॒रा वि॑विद्रे॒ सदु॒ नूत॑नासः ॥२॥

सत् । अस्य । मदे । सत् । ऊँ इति । अस्य । पीतौ । इन्द्रः । सत् । अस्य । सख्ये । चकार ।
रणाः । वा । ये । निसदि । सत् । ते । अस्य । पुरा । विविद्रे । सत् । ऊँ इति । नूतनासः ॥

sadasya made sadvasya pītāvindraḥ sadasya sakhye cakāra ।
raṇā vā ye niṣadi satte asya purā vividre sadu nūtanāsaḥ ॥

Drunk and intoxicated with the Truth and,
In Truth’s friendship has Indra done,
At the feet of the battle he acquired,
The Truth of the past and the Truth of the future.

न॒हि नु ते॑ महि॒मन॑: समस्य॒ न म॑घवन्मघव॒त्त्वस्य॑ वि॒द्म ।
न राध॑सोराधसो॒ नूत॑न॒स्येन्द्र॒ नकि॑र्ददृश इन्द्रि॒यं ते॑ ॥३॥

नहि । नु । ते । महिमनः । समस्य । न । मघवन् । मघवत्त्वस्य । विद्म ।
न । राधसःराधसः । नूतनस्य । इन्द्र । नकिः । ददृशे । इन्द्रियम् । ते ॥

nahi nu te mahimanaḥ samasya na maghavanmaghavattvasya vidma ।
na rādhasorādhaso nūtanasyendra nakirdadṛśa indriyaṃ te ॥

We do not know your vast powers, Maghvan,
The fullness of your greatness,
Nor has anyone seen (the like) of your,
Ever renewing generosity, O Indra.

ए॒तत्त्यत्त॑ इन्द्रि॒यम॑चेति॒ येनाव॑धीर्व॒रशि॑खस्य॒ शेष॑: ।
वज्र॑स्य॒ यत्ते॒ निह॑तस्य॒ शुष्मा॑त्स्व॒नाच्चि॑दिन्द्र पर॒मो द॒दार॑ ॥४॥

एतत् । त्यत् । ते । इन्द्रियम् । अचेति । येन । अवधीः । वरशिखस्य । शेषः ।
वज्रस्य । यत् । ते । निहतस्य । शुष्मात् । स्वनात् । चित् । इन्द्र । परमः । ददार ॥

etattyatta indriyamaceti yenāvadhīrvaraśikhasya śeṣaḥ ।
vajrasya yatte nihatasya śuṣmātsvanāccidindra paramo dadāra ॥

There is one that we have witnessed,
When you slew Varashikha’s end,
Even the thunderclap of your lightning bolt,
Was enough to destroy their best.

वधी॒दिन्द्रो॑ व॒रशि॑खस्य॒ शेषो॑ऽभ्याव॒र्तिने॑ चायमा॒नाय॒ शिक्ष॑न् ।
वृ॒चीव॑तो॒ यद्ध॑रियू॒पीया॑यां॒ हन्पूर्वे॒ अर्धे॑ भि॒यसाप॑रो॒ दर्त् ॥५॥

वधीत् । इन्द्रः । वरशिखस्य । शेषः । अभिआवर्तिने । चायमानाय । शिक्षन् ।
वृचीवतः । यत् । हरियूपीयायाम् । हन् । पूर्वे । अर्धे । भियसा । अपरः । दर्त् ॥

vadhīdindro varaśikhasya śeṣo’bhyāvartine cāyamānāya śikṣan ।
vṛcīvato yaddhariyūpīyāyāṃ hanpūrve ardhe bhiyasāparo dart ॥

For Abhyavartin Chayamana,
Indra destroyed Varasikha’s line.
At Hariyupiya he smote the vanguard,
Of the Vrcivat and their rear fled frightened.

त्रिं॒शच्छ॑तं व॒र्मिण॑ इन्द्र सा॒कं य॒व्याव॑त्यां पुरुहूत श्रव॒स्या ।
वृ॒चीव॑न्त॒: शर॑वे॒ पत्य॑माना॒: पात्रा॑ भिन्दा॒ना न्य॒र्थान्या॑यन् ॥६॥

त्रिंशत्शतम् । वर्मिणः । इन्द्र । साकम् । यव्यावत्याम् । पुरुहूत । श्रवस्या ।
वृचीवन्तः । शरवे । पत्यमानाः । पात्रा । भिन्दानाः । निअर्थानि । आयन् ॥

triṃśacchataṃ varmiṇa indra sākaṃ yavyāvatyāṃ puruhūta śravasyā ।
vṛcīvantaḥ śarave patyamānāḥ pātrā bhindānā nyarthānyāyan ॥

Thirty hundred armor-clad together,
On the Yavyavati, O much-sought after Indra,
Vrcivat’s sons fell to arrows,
Like bursting vessels and met their end.

यस्य॒ गावा॑वरु॒षा सू॑यव॒स्यू अ॒न्तरू॒ षु चर॑तो॒ रेरि॑हाणा ।
स सृञ्ज॑याय तु॒र्वशं॒ परा॑दाद्वृ॒चीव॑तो दैववा॒ताय॒ शिक्ष॑न् ॥७॥

यस्य । गावौ । अरुषा । सुयवस्यू इति सुयवस्यू । अन्तः । ऊँ इति । सु । चरतः । रेरिहाणा ।
सः । सृञ्जयाय । तुर्वशम् । परा । अदात् । वृचीवतः । दैववाताय । शिक्षन् ॥

yasya gāvāvaruṣā sūyavasyū antarū ṣu carato rerihāṇā ।
sa sṛñjayāya turvaśaṃ parādādvṛcīvato daivavātāya śikṣan ॥

Whose two red bulls plying their tongues,
For Soma between earth and heaven,
Gave the Turvasha to Srinjaya and,
Punished the Vrcivat for Daivavata.

द्व॒याँ अ॑ग्ने र॒थिनो॑ विंश॒तिं गा व॒धूम॑तो म॒घवा॒ मह्यं॑ स॒म्राट् ।
अ॒भ्या॒व॒र्ती चा॑यमा॒नो द॑दाति दू॒णाशे॒यं दक्षि॑णा पार्थ॒वाना॑म् ॥८॥

द्वयान् । अग्ने । रथिनः । विंशतिम् । गाः । वधूमतः । मघवा । मह्यम् । सम्राट् ।
अभिआवर्ती । चायमानः । ददाति । दुःनाशा । इयम् । दक्षिणा । पार्थवानाम् ॥

dvayām̐ agne rathino viṃśatiṃ gā vadhūmato maghavā mahyaṃ samrāṭ ।
abhyāvartī cāyamāno dadāti dūṇāśeyaṃ dakṣiṇā pārthavānām ॥

Two chariots of fire bridled with twenty oxen,
My generous lord gave me.
This imperishable gift of the Parthavas,
Was given to me by Abhyavartin Chayamana.

Translated by Devajyoti Sarkar

item.content:encoded:
The Nasadiya Sukta is famously known as the Creation Hymn of the Rig Veda. It speculates on cosmology and the origins of the universe. Carl Sagan quoted it in his discussion of the Indian “tradition of skeptical questioning and unselfconscious humility before the great cosmic mysteries.”

The Rig Veda is the most important work of ancient India. The Vedic corpus serves as the basis of almost all of modern Hindu thought and religion. The Nasadiya Sukta is the 129th Sukta of the tenth Mandala of the Rig Veda. The Rig Veda comprises of 10 books called “Mandalas”. They were composed by more than four hundred of the most famous sages of Indian tradition. The Rishi of this Sukta is Prajapati Parameshthin. It is dedicated to the Devata (God) Bhavavrittam which is another name for Brahma.

The Rig Veda represents a unique oral tradition that has been handed down with complete fidelity over thousands of years. Paradoxically, this accuracy has led to them to convey a voice that is both mysterious and beautiful. They talk about kings and events that are no longer remembered and Gods that are no longer worshiped. It comes from a time when humanity’s relationship to God was fundamentally different than today. Even the word “Sukta” means praise rather than prayer.

Rig Veda 10.129

Rishi: Prajapati Parmeshthin
Devata: Bhavavrittam

There was neither death nor immortality then,
There was neither day nor was there night,
That One breathed by his own will,
Apart from that there was nothing else.

Darkness was covered by darkness then,
Without form all this was Salil (water),
Emptiness was wrapped in emptiness,
Then Mahin took birth through Tapas (heat).

Desire kindled in that equanimity,
It became the first seed of the mind,
Existence found its friendship with non-existence,
So the sages discovered when they meditated.

Rays of light spread transversely,
Was there an above, was there a below?
There was the impregnator, there was Mahima,
The food was inferior, the eater superior.

Who knows it? Who here can claim to?
From where it came, this grand creation?
All the Gods came later,
Who knows now where it came from?

He from whom creation arose,
Maybe he upheld it or maybe not,
That Lord in the highest heaven,
Maybe he knows or maybe not.

Detailed Translation

नास॑दासी॒न्नो सदा॑सीत्त॒दानीं॒ नासी॒द्रजो॒ नो व्यो॑मा प॒रो त् ।
किमाव॑रीव॒: कुह॒ कस्य॒ शर्म॒न्नम्भ॒: किमा॑सी॒द्गह॑नं गभी॒रम् ॥१॥

न । अस॑त् । आ॒सी॒त् । नो इति॑ । सत् । आ॒सी॒त् । त॒दानी॑म् । न । आ॒सी॒त् । रजः॑ । नो इति॑ । विऽओ॑म । प॒रः । यत् ।
किम् । आ । अ॒व॒री॒व॒रिति॑ । कुह॑ । कस्य॑ । शर्म॑न् । अम्भः॑ । किम् । आ॒सी॒त् । गह॑नम् । ग॒भी॒रम् ॥

nāsadāsīnno sadāsīttadānīṃ nāsīdrajo no vyomā paro yat .
kimāvarīvaḥ kuha kasya śarmannambhaḥ kimāsīdgahanaṃ gabhīram ..

There was neither existence nor non-existence then,
There was neither the earth nor the heaven beyond,
What moved, in whose protection?
Was there water so very deep?

न मृ॒त्युरा॑सीद॒मृतं॒ न तर्हि॒ न रात्र्या॒ अह्न॑ आसीत्प्रके॒तः ।
आनी॑दवा॒तं स्व॒धया॒ तदेकं॒ तस्मा॑द्धा॒न्यन्न प॒रः किं च॒नास॑ ॥२॥

न । मृ॒त्युः । आ॒सी॒त् । अ॒मृत॑म् । न । तर्हि॑ । न । रात्र्याः॑ । अह्नः॑ । आ॒सी॒त् । प्र॒ऽके॒तः ।
आनी॑त् । अ॒वा॒तम् । स्व॒धया॑ । तत् । एक॑म् । तस्मा॑त् । ह॒ । अ॒न्यत् । न । प॒रः । किम् । च॒न । आ॒स॒ ॥

na mṛtyurāsīdamṛtaṃ na tarhi na rātryā ahna āsītpraketaḥ .
ānīdavātaṃ svadhayā tadekaṃ tasmāddhānyanna paraḥ kiṃ canāsa ..

There was neither death nor immortality then,
There was neither day nor was there night,
That One breathed by his own will,
Apart from that there was nothing else.

तम॑ आसी॒त्तम॑सा गू॒ळ्हमग्रे॑ऽप्रके॒तं स॑लि॒लं सर्व॑मा इ॒दम् ।
तु॒च्छ्येना॒भ्वपि॑हितं॒ यदासी॒त्तप॑स॒स्तन्म॑हि॒नाजा॑य॒तैक॑म् ॥३॥

तमः॑ । आ॒सी॒त् । तम॑सा । गू॒ळ्हम् । अग्रे॑ । अ॒प्र॒ऽके॒तम् । स॒लि॒लम् । सर्व॑म् । आः॒ । इ॒दम् ।
तु॒च्छ्येन॑ । आ॒भु । अपि॑ऽहितम् । यत् । आसी॑त् । तप॑सः । तत् । म॒हि॒ना । अ॒जा॒य॒त॒ । एक॑म् ॥

tama āsīttamasā gūl̤hamagre’praketaṃ salilaṃ sarvamā idam .
tucchyenābhvapihitaṃ yadāsīttapasastanmahinājāyataikam ..

Darkness was covered by darkness then,
Without form all this was Salil (water),
Emptiness was wrapped in emptiness,
Then Mahin took birth through Tapas (heat).

काम॒स्तदग्रे॒ सम॑वर्त॒ताधि॒ मन॑सो॒ रेत॑: प्रथ॒मं यदासी॑त् ।
स॒तो बन्धु॒मस॑ति॒ निर॑विन्दन्हृ॒दि प्र॒तीष्या॑ क॒वयो॑ मनी॒षा ॥४॥

कामः॑ । तत् । अग्रे॑ । सम् । अ॒व॒र्त॒त॒ । अधि॑ । मन॑सः । रेतः॑ । प्र॒थ॒मम् । यत् । आसी॑त् ।
स॒तः । बन्धु॑म् । अस॑ति । निः । अ॒वि॒न्द॒न् । हृ॒दि । प्र॒तीष्या॑ । क॒वयः॑ । म॒नी॒षा ॥

kāmastadagre samavartatādhi manaso retaḥ prathamaṃ yadāsīt .
sato bandhumasati niravindanhṛdi pratīṣyā kavayo manīṣā ..

Desire kindled in that equanimity,
It became the first seed of the mind,
Existence found its friendship with non-existence,
So the sages discovered when they meditated.

ति॒र॒श्चीनो॒ वित॑तो र॒श्मिरे॑षाम॒धः स्वि॑दा॒सी३दु॒परि॑ स्विदासी३त् ।
रे॒तो॒धा आ॑सन्महि॒मान॑ आसन्त्स्व॒धा अ॒वस्ता॒त्प्रय॑तिः प॒रस्ता॑त् ॥५॥

ति॒र॒श्चीनः॑ । विऽत॑तः । र॒श्मिः । ए॒षा॒म् । अ॒धः । स्वि॑त् । आ॒सी॒३त् । उ॒परि॑ । स्वित् । आ॒सी॒३त् ।
रे॒तः॒ऽधाः । आ॒स॒न् । म॒हि॒मानः॑ । आ॒स॒न् । स्व॒धा । अ॒वस्ता॑त् । प्रऽय॑तिः । प॒रस्ता॑त् ॥

tiraścīno vitato raśmireṣāmadhaḥ svidāsī3dupari svidāsī3t .
retodhā āsanmahimāna āsantsvadhā avastātprayatiḥ parastāt ..

Rays of light spread transversely,
Was there an above, was there a below?
There was the impregnator, there was Mahima,
The food was inferior, the eater superior.

को अ॒द्धा वे॑द॒ क इ॒ह प्र वो॑च॒त्कुत॒ आजा॑ता॒ कुत॑ इ॒यं विसृ॑ष्टिः ।
अ॒र्वाग्दे॒वा अ॒स्य वि॒सर्ज॑ने॒नाथा॒ को वे॑द॒ यत॑ आब॒भूव॑ ॥६॥

कः । अ॒द्धा । वे॒द॒ । कः । इ॒ह । प्र । वो॒च॒त् । कुतः॑ । आऽजा॑ता । कुतः॑ । इ॒यम् । विऽसृ॑ष्टिः ।
अ॒र्वाक् । दे॒वाः । अ॒स्य । वि॒ऽसर्ज॑नेन । अथ॑ । कः । वे॒द॒ । यतः॑ । आ॒ऽब॒भूव॑ ॥

ko addhā veda ka iha pra vocatkuta ājātā kuta iyaṃ visṛṣṭiḥ .
arvāgdevā asya visarjanenāthā ko veda yata ābabhūva ..

Who knows it? Who here can claim to?
From where it came, this grand creation?
All the Gods came later,
Who knows now where it came from?

इ॒यं विसृ॑ष्टि॒र्यत॑ आब॒भूव॒ यदि॑ वा द॒धे यदि॑ वा॒ न ।
यो अ॒स्याध्य॑क्षः पर॒मे व्यो॑म॒न्त्सो अ॒ङ्ग वे॑द॒ यदि॑ वा॒ न वेद॑ ॥७॥

इ॒यम् । विऽसृ॑ष्टिः । यतः॑ । आ॒ऽब॒भूव॑ । यदि॑ । वा॒ । द॒धे । यदि॑ । वा॒ । न ।
यः । अ॒स्य॒ । अधि॑ऽअक्षः । प॒र॒मे । विऽओ॑मन् । सः । अ॒ङ्ग । वे॒द॒ । यदि॑ । वा॒ । न । वेद॑ ॥

iyaṃ visṛṣṭiryata ābabhūva yadi vā dadhe yadi vā na .
yo asyādhyakṣaḥ parame vyomantso aṅga veda yadi vā na veda ..

He from whom creation arose,
Maybe he upheld it or maybe not,
That Lord in the highest heaven,
Maybe he knows or maybe not.
